children.subject:
thank you anon for a detailed answer!
based in what you said, would it be better (and possible) to take 127 w/o 16b?? 
and im wondering if i can take 189 w/o 188 as well. I would also appreciate if anyone can tell about his/her exprience w/ math 104 and 202a!! 
thanks :)

Same anon.

EE16b is a good purview for electrical engineering as a whole, but the only theoretical topic (although the practical side might be helpful in building intuition) of relevance for AI/ML is SVD which is easy to self-teach if you understand orthogonal decomposition. The first third or so of EE127 is a review of linear algebra, and I think Math 54 is sufficient background for it as long as you take the first third seriously and maybe take time to fill in the gaps that may exist in your knowledge, and you should be ready for the rest of the class, the actual optimization content. 

The experience with Math 104 really depends on the professor and their expectations of what is reasonable of undergraduate students. Usually the class has weekly problem sets (unless you take it with Hadfield) and they take about 10-15 hours each (although this can be as short as an hour if you get everything quickly). However I would recommend that if you take 104, you should take 105 before 202A since 104 alone doesn't prepare you enough. The other option is to take H104 which might be enough for 202A (although I would avoid it next semester since Wodzicki is teaching it).
Thank you so much for your kindness!!!

Could original anon comment further on Hadfield/Wodzicki? My plan right now is to take H104 with Wodzicki next semester, but I was also considering Hadfields section with just regular 104. I've heard Wodzicki is very difficult but is also loved by others.

To be fair I am biased against Wodzicki. He taught H113 for the past three spring semesters; the first and third time he taught he had fairly reasonable expectations of what the class should cover. The second time he had a completely unrealistic belief as to what undergraduates were capable of; by the end of the course he had started talking about Hopf algebras and I (and maybe most of the class?) had no clue what was going on. Week 10 I think he had assigned homework about 20 problems about kernels and cokernels in category theory and a lot of these were very hard questions. I had asked a friend at Harvard who was studying algebraic geometry (and had told me that the 55 series was pretty easy) for help and it took him 3 hours to solve one question (yeah that homework was awful, I also had a 70 midterm the day before and a 61b midterm the day of).

I have not had any experience with him teaching H104, but looking at the content it seems that he mostly focuses on point-set topology, which is great if you want to study that, but for a classical treatment of real analysis that contains metric space topology, differentiation, and Riemann integration I would recommend taking a regular 104 since it would be more useful for fields that require direct application of analysis (like statistics).

As for Hadfield, my experience with him is H185, and as a whole, he's a pretty decent professor. He's entertaining during lecture, and since he does differential geometry he draws plenty of pictures on the board to help with visualizing the theorems presented. However he skips a lot of details in proofs (although this was an honors course) which sometimes are not entirely nontrivial, and there are quite a few typos in his homeworks (and sometimes exams) which causes quite a bit of trouble (like flipping an inequality sign on a homework problem in a situation that is difficult to construct a counter-example).

Just my two cents.

Don't have much research experience personally so take what I say with a grain of salt (mostly comes from my friends). Generally EE126/127 are great foundational courses for content. To get research with professors that work in reinforcement learning, usually the requirement is to do well in 188 and 189 (but I think primarily 189). If you are interested in the statistical machine learning (and would want to apply to stats PhD program), what's more important is doing well in analysis courses like 104/105/202A (although 126 in a sense is an analysis course). These (and not Stat 134/135) are the foundational courses for advanced statistics and good grades in them indicate that you are ready for the rigor of a graduate statistics program.

For research specifically, you can just cold email professors, or check the websites of the professors you are interested in working with and see if they have specific guidelines for getting research with them. Even if they reject you, sometimes they will give a list of recommended courses or online content for self-study that, upon completion, get you a pretty good chance of getting research.

history.content:
Hello, I am a CS-intended rising sophomore who just declared the statistics major. (trying to double)


As I am mainly interested in exploring mathy-parts of CS and expanding their application to the world, I am planning to pursue phd in AI/ML, and thus interested in research opportunites.


I have taken Math 53 & 54 (a+ in these), Stat 134, CS 61A, CS70 (a in these).


Here, I want to ask for advice about courses to take in this Fall semester, especially classes that can help me get prepared for research in AI/statistics/machine learning/NLP.


I want to try my best to be part of research opportunites in next spring and summer.


I am pretty much set to take CS 61b, which I should have taken earlier, but everything else is undecided.


Other possible courses can be EECS 127, Stat 135, Stat 133, EE 16B, Math 126, or breadths.


(Here I am thinking about 17 ~ 20 units, strictly less than 5 techs)


Thank you so much for reading this wordy post ;)
history.subject: Which courses should I take to get ready for research opportunites as a sophomore? (such as 127?)

history.content:
Hello, I am a CS-intended rising sophomore who just declared the statistics major. (trying to double)


As I am mainly interested in exploring mathy-parts of CS and expanding their application to the world, I am planning to pursue phd in AI/ML, and thus interested in research opportunites.


I have taken Math 53 & 54 (a+ in these), Stat 134, CS 61A, CS70 (a in these).


Here, I want to ask for advice about courses to take in this Fall semester, especially classes that can help me get prepared for research in AI/statistics/machine learning/NLP.


I want to try my best to be part of research opportunites in next spring and summer.


I am pretty much set to take CS 61b, which I should have taken earlier, but everything else is undecided.


Other possible courses can be EECS 127, Stat 135, Stat 133, EE 16B, Math 126, or breadths.


(Here I am thinking about 17 ~ 20 units, strictly less than 5 techs)



Also, I would really really appreciate if you could advise me about how to start looking for research at the right level.


Am I ready for participating in research? or should I start as an apprentice? (like URAP)


I don't have any research experience, though I have done one internship related to basic text-mining.



Thank you so much for reading this wordy post ;)
